title: Chapter 2 Quiz: Robot Components and Architecture
description: Test your understanding of humanoid robot hardware, software architecture, and power systems.

questions.question: What is the typical hierarchy in humanoid robot software architecture?
options: B. Hardware → Low-Level Control → Mid-Level Control → High-Level Planning
questions.explanation: Humanoid robot architecture follows a hierarchical design where low-level hardware interfaces with low-level control (motor control, sensor processing), which connects to mid-level control (motion planning), coordinated by high-level planning (AI, task planning).

questions.question: What type of joint allows rotation around a single axis?
questions.explanation: A revolute joint allows rotation around a single axis, similar to a door hinge. It provides one degree of freedom and is the most common joint type in humanoid robots.

questions.question: Series Elastic Actuators (SEA) are preferred for human-robot interaction because they provide compliance and force sensing.
questions.explanation: SEAs include a spring between the motor and load, which provides natural compliance (giving way under unexpected forces) and allows force measurement through spring deflection, making them safer for human interaction.

questions.question: Which battery technology offers the highest energy density for humanoid robots?
questions.explanation: Lithium-ion batteries offer high energy density (150-250 Wh/kg) and are the most common choice for modern humanoid robots due to their favorable power-to-weight ratio and rechargeability.

questions.question: What is ROS 2 and why is it important in humanoid robotics?
questions.correct_answer: ROS 2 (Robot Operating System 2) is the standard middleware for robotics that provides communication infrastructure, tools, and libraries for building robot applications.
questions.explanation: ROS 2 is essential because it provides a standardized framework for robot software development, including inter-process communication, hardware abstraction, package management, and a rich ecosystem of tools and algorithms.
